title: How many business applications will be made in the US in 2021?
possible_answers: More than 5.2 million but fewer than 5.6 million
correct_answer: More than 5.2 million but fewer than 5.6 million
preds: Given the historical distribution of MoM changes november to december (2004/2020 in %) the probability of it being less than 5.2M and more than 5.6M is close to 0%. There had to be a world shattering event for the business applications in December to drop or rise in a way that would shift the historical pattern. I see no signs in the news for such an event.

It was 4.5M in 2020, and that was a 24% rise on 2019. 4.8M is an additional 7%, 5.2M is an additional 17%, 5.6M is an additional 24%. Some further growth is plausible, but as the economy stabilised in 2021 and employment was on the rise, the same sort of growth y-o-y would not be expected in my view.
based on trend analysis using existing data

Trend analysis of latest monthly figures indicates applications will be between 5.2 and 5.6 million. However, past years indicate a surge in business applications towards the end of the year. Business applications have remained elevated throughout the pandemic even as labour market instability has persisted. Challenges regarding business operations including evolving nature of the pandemic, supply bottlenecks and high producer and consumer inflation all pose as potential barriers to new business creation.

If you play with the numbers a little you will see there is not a lot of variance in the numbers of business application in a month as a any kind of average (I tried rolling aves, and as per calendar year), until 2020 - given this data goes back to 2004, it suggests to me there is a fairly even spread of business creation, even when there is turmoil, but not nationwide catastrophe.  My second thought is now we are shifting out of the initial phases of the pandemic, I think we will see a slight decline on the initial business application numbers, as the country continues to open up, people lucky enough to have the choice won't have to submit business applications to work, they can go find work. Noting that in the medium-to-long term, these numbers will remain significantly higher than pre-pandemic.  As the number to end of Aug is 3.68M, I think surpassing 6M is close to 0% (this requires a 4-month average higher than the highest month on record).
Adjusting downward upon a "second look." I think the crowd median is highly biased and therefore won't put too much weight in it. This is a freestyle forecast based on my own judgement.

a preliminary estimate based on the numbers reported so far, mostly inline with what the crowd believes,
Will update as i read more
Was using an incorrect formula.  Updated to reflect correction.

Major reroute. I blindly followed crowd for the sake of getting my foot in the door but having a convenient ballpark estimate, but upon my analysis, I think this should be shifted toward the first 3 bins, favoring bin #2. This forecast combines some of the crowd median with my independent percentages. If this shift turns out to be a good move, I feel some of us are just lazily averaging other forecasts without adding much intellectual insight to this website besides chasing good brier scores. You can have a good brier score by aggregating but you'd be in the dark if you were asked to make forecasts without seeing other people's opinions, which the OG superforecasters had to do.

An update based on the 2021 August figures being recently released. I found that the total amount from January - August comprises between [63.9% - 68.0%] of the total year amounts. Therefore, with the 2021 January - August amount equalling 3,684,127 ->
Minimum Value Of 2021 Total Amount = 5,417,834 = 3,684,127 / .680
Maximum Value Of 2021 Total Amount = 5,765,457 = 3,684,127 / .639 However within this range the data is heavily concentrated in the [5.21 - 5.59] option ->
[5.21 - 5.59] = 69% = 11 /16
[5.60 - 6.00] = 31% = 5 / 16

I calculated the standard normal distribution after forecasting the existing trend (Scenario #1 - using 2021 YTD data; Scenario #2 - using the past 10 weeks of data). I averaged the resulting probabilities.

Using the data from 2005 - 2020 ->
https://www.census.gov/econ/currentdata/dbsearch?program=BFS&startYear=2004&endYear=2021&categories=TOTAL&dataType=BA_BA&geoLevel=US&adjusted=1&submit=GET+DATA&releaseScheduleId= I found that the total amount from January - July comprises between [52.9% - 59.2%] of the total year amounts. Therefore, with the 2021 January - July amount equalling 3,264,655 ->
Minimum Value Of 2021 Total Amount = 5,514,620 = 3,264,655 / .592
Maximum Value Of 2021 Total Amount  = 6,171,371 = 3,264,655 / .529 However within this range the data is heavily concentrated in the [5.60 - 6.00] option ->
[5.21 - 5.59] = 25% = 4 /16
[5.60 - 6.00] = 69% = 11 / 16
[6.01 >= x] = 6% = 1 / 16
